article.title: Gravitational waves from isolated neutron stars: mass dependence of r-mode instability

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the nuclear symmetry energy (NSE) represent in the context of nuclear matter?
choices: The binding energy difference between symmetric nuclear matter (SNM) and pure neutron matter (PNM) at a given density.
The energy required to compress SNM to a given density.
The difference in Fermi momentum between protons and neutrons in isospin asymmetric nuclear matter.
The strength of the DDM3Y interaction in SNM.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the dotted rectangular region in the plot of  Kτ versus K∞?
choices: It represents the range of theoretically predicted values for K∞ and Kτ.
It highlights the region where both DDM3Y and SkI3 models agree with experimental data.
It encompasses the experimentally determined values for K∞ and Kτ.
It shows the region where the DDM3Y interaction provides the best fit to experimental data.

multiple_choice_question.text: What can be inferred from the close proximity of the continuous and dashed lines in the plot of pressure (P) versus density (ρ/ρ0)?
choices: The pressure of pure neutron matter is significantly higher than that of β-equilibrated neutron star matter.
The DDM3Y model predicts a very stiff equation of state for neutron star matter.
The pressure contribution from the symmetry energy is negligible at high densities.
The pressure of β-equilibrated neutron star matter is similar to that of pure neutron matter at high densities.

multiple_choice_question.text: According to Formula (17), what is the relationship between the critical angular velocity (Ωc) and temperature (T)?
choices: Ωc is independent of T.
Ωc increases linearly with T.
Ωc decreases with increasing T.
Ωc is inversely proportional to T.

multiple_choice_question.text: Formula (47) indicates that the critical angular velocity (Ωc) is dependent on several factors. Which of the following is NOT one of these factors?
choices: Neutron star mass (M).
Radius of the neutron star (R).
Core-crust transition density (ρt).
Crustal thickness.
